column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: In celebration of Hispanic Heritage Month, James Hardie's AMIGOS invited a guest speaker to present how Hispanic culture, values and personality traits are invaluable to innovation and how to leverage these assets to succeed.
column20: AMIGOS, Hispanic Heritage Month, Hispanic culture

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: James Hardie's Asian Pacific Network (ASPAN) sponsored educational forums to celebrate APAC Heritage Month and Eid al-Fitr Festival, when Muslims worldwide celebrate the end of the fasting month of Ramadan.
column20: ASPAN, educational forum, Eid al-Fitr Festival

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: James Hardie's Black Engagement produced a weekly newsletter highlighting James Hardie employees to celebrate Black History Month. It was accompanied by a Q&A focused on why diversity is important and what it means to them.
column20: Black Engagement, weekly newsletter, Black History Month

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: During Pride Month, James Hardie launched the Pride Employee Resource Group with a virtual educational event, followed by blogs and social media posts on key dates throughout the year to acknowledge and celebrate the LGBTQIA+ voices of James Hardie's associates, partners and consumers.

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: James Hardie's Women's Initiative Network held International Women's Day 2023 celebrations across James Hardie's locations in North America and around the globe to raise awareness, focusing on the difference between equity and equality.
column20: Women's Initiative Network, Women's Day, equity, equality

Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: In 2021, the Grizzly Flats community in Northern California was devastated by the Caldor Fire. James Hardie partnered with the Pioneer Volunteer Firefighters Association and West Slope Foundation to donate Hardie siding to help Grizzly Flats recover. James Hardie also offered a rebate to homeowners affected by the Caldor Fire to help make rebuilding more affordable.
column20: Grizzly Flats, Caldor Fire, West Slope Foundation

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: James Hardie collaborated with one of its customers to support the Idaho Youth Ranch by donating more than 29,000 square feet of Hardie Plank and Hardie Trim to construct new state-of-the-art facilities in Caldwell, Idaho. The campus will provide youth with long-term residential care to transform childhood trauma into hope, healing and resilience.
column20: Idaho Youth Ranch, donation, residential care

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column9: Habitat for Humanity of Autauga and Chilton Counties
column13: James Hardie's manufacturing plant in Prattville, Alabama, supported Habitat for Humanity of Autauga and Chilton Counties by donating siding and soffit, along with creating volunteer opportunities for its employees, to make a meaningful impact on the lives of Habitat for Humanity homeowners.
column20: Habitat for Humanity of Autauga and Chilton Counties, volunteer opportunity, donation

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: As part of Women In Construction Week, James Hardie donated Hardie Plank to Dorchester Habitat for Humanity in Summerville, South Carolina, to support the organisation's "Women Build" event, which boasted nearly 300 women coming together to build a house in support of a single mother.
column20: Women in Construction Week, Habitat for Humanity, Women Build

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: When devastating tornadoes tore through Kentucky and Tennessee, James Hardie partnered with local chapters of Habitat for Humanity to donate 108,000 square feet of siding, trim and soffit to support the building of homes for needy families.

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: A fund of over $3,000 was created from employee donations and James Hardie matching dollars that veterans in James Hardie's US workforce could donate to any charity. James Hardie's veterans decided to split the fund between three different charitable organisations.

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: James Hardie worked with New River Community Action to create 240 "blessing bags" to benefit people experiencing homelessness. James Hardie employee Nicole Bowman created the fundraising idea of a blessing bag containing personal care products. James Hardie's employees also volunteered to assemble and deliver the bags to those in the greatest need.
column20: New River Community Action, blessing bag, homelessness

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: James Hardie's employees climbed 80 floors to the top of the AON Center, one of Chicago's tallest buildings, to raise funds for the Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago.
column20: AON Centre, fundraising, Hospital of Chicago

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: James Hardie's Australia offices hosted their annual Christmas raffle, which benefits charitable organisations annually. In 2022, nearly AUD 9,000 was raised from raffle participants, matched by James Hardie and then donated evenly between two charities: the Black Dog Institute and the School Project.
column20: Chrismas raffle, charitable organisation, Black Dog Institute
